GlobalVariables.StudyDescription: Study Data Tabulation Model Implementation Guide: Human Clinical Trials Version 3.3 (Final)

ItemGroupDef.Name: CO
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per comment per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: DM
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: SE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per actual Element per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: SM
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per Disease Milestone per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: SV
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per subject per actual visit

ItemGroupDef.Name: AG
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per recorded intervention occurrence per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: CM
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per recorded intervention occurrence or constant-dosing interval per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: EX
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per protocol-specified study treatment, constant-dosing interval, per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: EC
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per protocol-specified study treatment, collected-dosing interval, per subject, per mood

ItemGroupDef.Name: ML
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per food product occurrence or constant intake interval per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: PR
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per recorded procedure per occurrence per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: SU
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per substance type per reported occurrence per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: AE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per adverse event per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: CE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per event per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: DS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per disposition status or protocol milestone per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: DV
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per protocol deviation per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: HO
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per healthcare encounter per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: MH

ItemGroupDef.Name: DA
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per drug accountability finding per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: DD
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: EG
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per ECG observation per replicate per time point or one record per ECG observation per beat per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: IE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per inclusion/exclusion criterion not met per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: IS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per test per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: LB
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per lab test per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: MB
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per microbiology specimen finding per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: MS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per microbiology susceptibility test (or other organism-related finding) per organism found in MB

ItemGroupDef.Name: MI
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding per specimen per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: MO
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per Morphology finding per location per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: CV
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding or result per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: MK
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per assessment per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: NV
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding per location per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: OE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per ophthalmic finding per method per location, per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: RP
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding or result per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: RE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding or result per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: UR
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding per location per per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: PC
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per sample characteristic or time-point concentration per reference time point or per analyte per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: PP
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per PK parameter per time-concentration profile per modeling method per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: PE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per body system or abnormality per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: FT
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per Functional Test finding per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: QS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per questionnaire per question per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: RS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per response assessment or clinical classification assessment per time point per visit per subject per assessor per medical evaluator

ItemGroupDef.Name: SC
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per characteristic per subject.

ItemGroupDef.Name: SS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: TU
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per identified tumor per subject per assessor

ItemGroupDef.Name: TR
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per tumor measurement/assessment per visit per subject per assessor

ItemGroupDef.Name: VS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per vital sign measurement per time point per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: FA
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding, per object, per time point, per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: SR
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per finding, per object, per time point, per visit per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: TA
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per planned Element per Arm

ItemGroupDef.Name: TE
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per planned Element

ItemGroupDef.Name: TV
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per planned Visit per Arm

ItemGroupDef.Name: TD
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per planned constant assessment period

ItemGroupDef.Name: TM
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per Disease Milestone type

ItemGroupDef.Name: TI
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per I/E crierion

ItemGroupDef.Name: TS
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per trial summary parameter value

ItemGroupDef.Name: RELREC
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per related record, group of records or dataset

ItemGroupDef.Name: SUPPQUAL
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per IDVAR, IDVARVAL, and QNAM value per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: RELSUB
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per relationship per related subject per subject

ItemGroupDef.Name: OI
ItemGroupDef.def:Structure: One record per taxon per non-host organism

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s). Null for comments collected on a general comments or additional information CRF page.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Identifying variable in the parent dataset that identifies the record(s) to which the comment applies. Examples AESEQ or CMGRPID. Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.
Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s). Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.

Sponsor-defined reference associated with the comment. May be the CRF page number (e.g., 650), or a module name (e.g., DEMOG), or a combination of information that identifies the reference (e.g. 650-VITALS-VISIT 2).
The text of the comment. Text over 200 characters can be added to additional columns COVAL1-COVALn. See Assumption 3.
Used to describe the originator of the comment. Examples: CENTRAL, REVIEWER, ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE, PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR.
Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in --EVAL. Examples: RADIOLOGIST, RADIOLOGIST1, RADIOLOGIST2.
Date/time of comment on dedicated comment form. Should be null if this is a child record of another domain or if comment date was not collected.
Study day of the comment, in integer days. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product. This must be a unique number, and could be a compound identifier formed by concatenating STUDYID-SITEID-SUBJID.
Subject identifier, which must be unique within the study. Often the ID of the subject as recorded on a CRF.

Reference Start Date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 character format. Usually equivalent to date/time when subject was first exposed to study treatment. See Assumption 9 for additional detail on when RFSTDTC may be null.

Reference End Date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 character format. Usually equivalent to the date/time when subject was determined to have ended the trial, and often equivalent to date/time of last exposure to study treatment. Required for all randomized subjects; null for screen failures or unassigned subjects.
First date/time of exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, equal to the earliest value of EXSTDTC.
Last date/time of exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, equal to the latest value of EXENDTC (or the latest value of EXSTDTC if EXENDTC was not collected or is missing).

Date/time of informed consent in ISO 8601 character format. This will be the same as the date of informed consent in the Disposition domain, if that protocol milestone is documented. Would be null only in studies not collecting the date of informed consent.

Date/time when subject ended participation or follow-up in a trial, as defined in the protocol, in ISO 8601 character format. Should correspond to the last known date of contact. Examples include completion date, withdrawal date, last follow-up, date recorded for lost to follow up, or death date.
Date/time of death for any subject who died, in ISO 8601 format. Should represent the date/time that is captured in the clinical-trial database.
Indicates the subject died. Should be "Y" or null. Should be populated even when the death date is unknown.
Unique identifier for a site within a study.
An identifier to describe the Investigator for the study. May be used in addition to SITEID. Not needed if SITEID is equivalent to INVID.
Name of the investigator for a site.
Date/time of birth of the subject.
Age expressed in AGEU. May be derived from RFSTDTC and BRTHDTC, but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases (due to subject privacy concerns).
Units associated with AGE.
Sex of the subject.

Race of the subject. Sponsors should refer to "Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials" (FDA, October, 2016) for guidance regarding the collection of race (https://www.fda.gov/downloads/regulatoryinformation/guidances/ucm126396.pdf) See Assumption below regarding RACE.

The ethnicity of the subject. Sponsors should refer to "Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials" (FDA, October, 2016) for guidance regarding the collection of ethnicity (https://www.fda.gov/downloads/regulatoryinformation/guidances/ucm126396.pdf).

ARMCD is limited to 20 characters. It is not subject to the character restrictions that apply to TESTCD.The maximum length of ARMCD is longer than for other "short" variables to accommodate the kind of values that are likely to be needed for crossover trials. For example, if ARMCD values for a seven-period crossover were constructed using two-character abbreviations for each treatment and separating hyphens, the length of ARMCD values would be 20. If the subject was not assigned to an Arm, ARMCD is null and ARMNRS is populated. With the exception of studies which use multi-stage Arm assignments, must be a value of ARMCD in the Trial Arms Dataset.

Name of the Arm to which the subject was assigned. If the subject was not assigned to an Arm, ARM is null and ARMNRS is populated. With the exception of studies which use multi-stage Arm assignments, must be a value of ARM in the Trial Arms Dataset.

Code of actual Arm. ACTARMCD is limited to 20 characters. It is not subject to the character restrictions that apply to TESTCD. The maximum length of ACTARMCD is longer than for other short variables to accommodate the kind of values that are likely to be needed for crossover trials. With the exception of studies which use multi-stage Arm assignments, must be a value of ARMCD in the Trial Arms Dataset. If the subject was not assigned to an Arm or followed a course not described by any planned Arm, ACTARMCD is null and ARMNRS is populated.

Description of actual Arm. With the exception of studies which use multi-stage Arm assignments, must be a value of ARM in the Trial Arms Dataset. If the subject was not assigned to an Arm or followed a course not described by any planned Arm, ACTARM is null and ARMNRS is populated.

Description.TranslatedText: Reason Arm and/or Actual Arm is Null

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: A coded reason that Arm variables (ARM and ARMCD) and/or actual Arm variables (ACTARM and ACTARMCD) are null. Examples: "SCREEN FAILURE", "NOT ASSIGNED", "ASSIGNED, NOT TREATED", "UNPLANNED TREATMENT". It is assumed that if the Arm and actual Arm variables are null, the same reason applies to both Arm and actual Arm.
A description of actual treatment for a subject who did not receive treatment described in one of the planned trial Arms.
Country of the investigational site in which the subject participated in the trial.
Date/time of demographic data collection.
Study day of collection measured as integer days.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. Should be assigned to be consistent chronological order.

1. ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that ETCD will need to serve as a variable name. 2. If an encountered Element differs from the planned Element to the point that it is considered a new Element, then use "UNPLAN" as the value for ETCD to represent this Element.
The name of the Element. If ETCD has a value of "UNPLAN" then ELEMENT should be null.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the subject's assigned Arm.
Epoch associated with the Element in the planned sequence of Elements for the Arm to which the subject was assigned.
Start date/time for an Element for each subject.
End date/time for an Element for each subject.
Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned Element. Used only if ETCD has the value of "UNPLAN".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies.
Sequence number to ensure uniqueness of subject records. Should be assigned to be consistent chronological order.
Name of the specific Disease Milestone. For types of Disease Milestone that can occur multiple times, the name will end with a sequence number. Example: "HYPO1".
The type of Disease Milestone. Example: "HYPOGLYCEMIC EVENT".
State date/time of Milestone Instance, if Milestone is an intervention or event, or date of Milestone if Milestone is a finding.
End date/time of Disease Milestone Instance.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Milestone

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of Disease Milestone Instance, relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Milestone

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of Disease Milestone Instance, relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
1. Clinical encounter number. (Decimal numbering may be useful for inserting unplanned visits.) 2. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.
1. Protocol-defined description of clinical encounter. 2. May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY as a text description of the clinical encounter.
Planned study day of the start of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.
Start date/time for a Visit.
End date/time of a Visit.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Visit

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of visit relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Visit

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of visit relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned visit.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number from the procedure or test page.
Identifier used to link related records across domains.This may be a one-to-one or a one-to-many relationship.
Identifier used to link related records across domains.This will usually be a many-to-one relationship.
Verbatim medication name that is either pre-printed or collected on a CRF.
If AGTRT is modified to facilitate coding, then AGMODIFY will contain the modified text.

Standardized or dictionary-derived text description of AGTRT or AGMODIFY. Equivalent to the generic medication name in WHO Drug. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document. If an intervention term does not have a decode value in the dictionary, then AGDECOD will be left blank.
Used to define a category of agent. Examples: "CHALLENGE AGENT", or "PET TRACER".
Further categorization of agent.
Used to indicate whether ("Y"/null) information about the use of a specific agent was solicited on the CRF.
When the use of specific agent is solicited, AGOCCUR is used to indicate whether or not ("Y"/"N") use of the agent occurred. Values are null for agents not specifically solicited.
Used to indicate that a question about a pre-specified agent was not answered. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".
Describes the reason a response to a question about the occurrence of a procedure agent was not collected. Used in conjunction with AGSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Drug class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class value. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, then follow assumption 4.1.2.8.3 or omit AGCLAS.

Class code corresponding to AGCLAS. Drug class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class code. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, then follow Assumption 4.1.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-Result Qualifier Variable, or omit AGCLASCD.
Amount of AGTRT taken.
Dosing amounts or a range of dosing information collected in text form. Units may be stored in AGDOSU. Example: "200-400", "15-20".
Units for AGDOSE and AGDOSTXT. Examples: "ng", "mg", or "mg/kg".
Dose form for AGTRT. Examples: "TABLET", "AEROSOL".
Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of AGDOSE within a specific time period. Example: "ONCE".
Route of administration for AGTRT. Examples: "ORAL".
1. Clinical encounter number. 2. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.
1. Protocol-defined description of clinical encounter. 2. May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY.
Planned study day of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm for the Element in which the agent administration started.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the agent administration started.
The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by AGTRT and the dosing variables began.
The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by AGTRT and the dosing variables ended.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Agent

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of agent relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Agent

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of agent relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Collected duration for an agent episode. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.

Describes the start of the agent relative to sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING", or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into AGSTRF.

Describes the end of the agent relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING", or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into AGENRF.

Description.TranslatedText: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the start of the agent as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable AGSTTPT.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by AGSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the agent as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable AGENTPT. Identifies the end of the agent as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable AGENTPT.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by AGENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence number to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Sponsor-defined reference number. Example: a number pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or record identifier defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: line number on a concomitant medication page.

Description.TranslatedText: Reported Name of Drug, Med, or Therapy

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Verbatim medication name that is either pre-printed or collected on a CRF.
If CMTRT is modified to facilitate coding, then CMMODIFY will contain the modified text.

Standardized or dictionary-derived text description of CMTRT or CMMODIFY. Equivalent to the generic drug name in WHO Drug. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document. If an intervention term does not have a decode value in the dictionary, then CMDECOD will be left blank.
Used to define a category of medications/treatment. Examples: "PRIOR", "CONCOMITANT", "ANTI-CANCER MEDICATION", or "GENERAL CONMED".
A further categorization of medications/treatment. Examples: "CHEMOTHERAPY", "HORMONAL THERAPY", "ALTERNATIVE THERAPY".
Used to indicate whether ("Y"/null) information about the use of a specific medication was solicited on the CRF.
When the use of a specific medication is solicited. CMOCCUR is used to indicate whether or not ("Y"/"N") use of the medication occurred. Values are null for medications not specifically solicited.
Used to indicate that a question about the occurrence of a pre-specified intervention was not answered. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".
Reason not done. Used in conjunction with CMSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".
Denotes why a medication was taken or administered. Examples: "NAUSEA", "HYPERTENSION".

Drug class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class value. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, then follow Section 4.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-Result Qualifier Variable, or omit CMCLAS.

Class code corresponding to CMCLAS. Drug class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class code. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, then follow Section 4.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-Result Qualifier Variable, or omit CMCLASCD.
Amount of CMTRT given. Not populated when CMDOSTXT is populated.
Dosing amounts or a range of dosing information collected in text form. Units may be stored in CMDOSU. Examples: "200-400", "15-20". Not populated when CMDOSE is populated.
Units for CMDOSE, CMDOSTOT, or CMDOSTXT. Examples: "ng", "mg", or "mg/kg".
Dose form for CMTRT. Examples: "TABLET", "LOTION".
Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of CMDOSE within a specific time period. Examples: "BID" (twice daily), "Q12H" (every 12 hours).

Total daily dose of CMTRT using the units in CMDOSU. Used when dosing is collected as Total Daily Dose. Total dose over a period other than day could be recorded in a separate Supplemental Qualifier variable.
Text description of the (intended) schedule or regimen for the Intervention. Example: "TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF".
Route of administration for the intervention. Examples: "ORAL", "INTRAVENOUS".
Describes reason or explanation of why a dose is adjusted. Examples: "ADVERSE EVENT", "INSUFFICIENT RESPONSE", "NON-MEDICAL REASON".
When dosing of a treatment is recorded over multiple successive records, this variable is applicable only for the (chronologically) last record for the treatment.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm for the Element in which the medication administration started. Null for medications that started before study participation.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the medication administration. Null for medications that started before study participation.
Start date/time of the medication administration represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of the medication administration represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Medication

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of medication relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Medication

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of medication relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Collected duration for a treatment episode. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.

Describes the start of the medication relative to sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR" was collected, this information may be translated into CMSTRF. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Describes the end of the medication relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING, or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into CMENRF. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Description.TranslatedText: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the start of the medication as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable CMSTTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by CMSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the medication as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable CMENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by CMENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external identifier (e.g., kit number, bottle label, vial identifier).
Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a CRF Page.
Identifier used to link related records across domains.
Identifier used to link related, grouped records across domains.
Name of the protocol-specified study treatment given during the dosing period for the observation.
Used to define a category of EXTRT values.
A further categorization of EXCAT values.
Amount of EXTRT when numeric. Not populated when EXDOSTXT is populated.
Amount of EXTRT when non-numeric. Dosing amounts or a range of dosing information collected in text form. Example: 200-400. Not populated when EXDOSE is populated.
Units for EXDOSE, EXDOSTOT, or EXDOSTXT representing protocol-specified values. Examples: "ng", "mg", "mg/kg", "mg/m2".
Dose form for EXTRT. Examples: "TABLET", "LOTION".
Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of EXDOSE within a specific time period. Examples: "Q2H", "QD", "BID".
Text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the Intervention. Example: "TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF".
Route of administration for the intervention. Examples: "ORAL", "INTRAVENOUS".
Lot number of the intervention product.
Specifies location of administration. Examples: "ARM", "LIP".
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing laterality of the intervention administration. Examples: "LEFT", "RIGHT".
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing directionality. Examples: "ANTERIOR", "LOWER", "PROXIMAL", "UPPER".
Indicator used to identify fasting status. Examples: "Y", "N".
Describes reason or explanation of why a dose is adjusted.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.
Trial Epoch of the Exposure record. Examples: "RUN-IN", "TREATMENT".
The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by EXTRT and EXDOSE began.

The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by EXTRT and EXDOSE ended. For administrations considered given at a point in time (e.g., oral tablet, pre-filled syringe injection), where only an administration date/time is collected, EXSTDTC should be copied to EXENDTC as the standard representation.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Treatment

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of EXSTDTC relative to DM.RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Treatment

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of EXENDTC relative to DM.RFSTDTC.
Collected duration of administration. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.
1. Text Description of time when administration should occur. 2. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See EXTPTNUM and EXTPTREF.
Numerical version of EXTPT to aid in sorting.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Planned elapsed time relative to the planned fixed reference (EXTPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time.
Name of the fixed reference point referred to by EXELTM, EXTPTNUM, and EXTPT. Examples: PREVIOUS DOSE, PREVIOUS MEAL.
Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by EXTPTREF.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external identifier (e.g., kit number, bottle label, vial identifier).
Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a CRF Page.
Identifier used to link related records across domains.
Identifier used to link related, grouped records across domains.
Name of the intervention treatment known to the subject and/or administrator.

Mode or condition of the record specifying whether the intervention (activity) is intended to happen or has happened. Values align with BRIDG pillars (e.g., scheduled context, performed context) and HL7 activity moods (e.g., intent, event). Examples: "SCHEDULED", "PERFORMED".
Used to define a category of related ECTRT values.
A further categorization of ECCAT values.
Used when a specific intervention is pre-specified. Values should be "Y" or null.
Used to indicate whether a treatment occurred when information about the occurrence is solicited. ECOCCUR = "N" when a treatment was not taken, not given, or missed.
Amount of ECTRT when numeric. Not populated when ECDOSTXT is populated.
Amount of ECTRT when non-numeric. Dosing amounts or a range of dosing information collected in text form. Example: "200-400". Not populated when ECDOSE is populated.
Units for ECDOSE, ECDOSTOT, or ECDOSTXT.
Dose form for ECTRT. Examples: "TABLET", "LOTION".
Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of ECDOSE within a specific time period. Examples: "Q2H", "QD", "BID".
Total daily dose of ECTRT using the units in ECDOSU. Used when dosing is collected as Total Daily Dose.
Text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the Intervention. Example: "TWO WEEKS ON", "TWO WEEKS OFF".
Route of administration for the intervention. Examples: "ORAL", "INTRAVENOUS".
Lot Number of the ECTRT product.
Specifies location of administration. Example: "ARM", "LIP".
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing laterality of the intervention administration. Examples: "LEFT", "RIGHT".
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing directionality. Examples: "ANTERIOR", "LOWER", "PROXIMAL", "UPPER".
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing distribution, which means arrangement of, apportioning of. Examples: "ENTIRE", "SINGLE", "SEGMENT".
Indicator used to identify fasting status. Examples: "Y", "N".
Amount of an active ingredient expressed quantitatively per dosage unit, per unit of volume, or per unit of weight, according to the pharmaceutical dose form.
Unit for ECPSTRG. Examples: "mg/TABLET", "mg/mL".
Describes reason or explanation of why a dose is adjusted.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.
Trial Epoch of the exposure as collected record. Examples: "RUN-IN", "TREATMENT".
The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by ECTRT and ECDOSE began.

The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by ECTRT and ECDOSE ended. For administrations considered given at a point in time (e.g., oral tablet, pre-filled syringe injection), where only an administration date/time is collected, ECSTDTC should be copied to ECENDTC as the standard representation.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Treatment

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of ECSTDTC relative to the sponsor-defined DM.RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Treatment

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of ECENDTC relative to the sponsor-defined DM.RFSTDTC.
Collected duration of administration. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.
Text Description of time when administration should occur. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See ECTPTNUM and ECTPTREF.
Numerical version of ECTPT to aid in sorting.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Planned elapsed time relative to the planned fixed reference (ECTPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time.
Name of the fixed reference point referred to by ECELTM, ECTPTNUM, and ECTPT. Examples: PREVIOUS DOSE, PREVIOUS MEAL.
Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by ECTPTREF.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Sponsor-defined reference number. Examples: a number pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or record identifier defined in the sponsor's operational database.
Verbatim food product name that is either pre-printed or collected on a CRF.
Used to define a category of MLTRT values.
Used to define a further categorization of MLCAT values.
Used when a specific meal is pre-specified on a CRF. Values should be "Y" or null.
Used to record whether a pre-specified meal occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific meal is solicited.
Used to indicate when a question about the occurrence of a pre-specified meal was not answered. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".
Describes the reason a response to a question about the occurrence of a meal was not collected. Used in conjunction with MLSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".
Amount of MLTRT consumed. Not populated when MLDOSTXT is populated.
Amount description of MLTRT consumed, collected in text form. Not populated when MLDOSE is populated. Examples: "<1 per day", "200-400".
Units for MLDOSE, MLDOSTOT, or MLDOSTXT.
Dosage form for MLTRT. Example: "BAR, CHEWABLE".
Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.
Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter.
Planned study day of VISIT. Should be an integer.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm for the Element in which the meal started.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the meal.
Collection date and time of the meal represented in ISO 8601 character format.
Start date/time of the meal represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of the meal represented in ISO 8601 character format.
Actual study day of the visit/collection expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Meal

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Actual study day of start of the meal expressed in integer days relative to sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Meal

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Actual study day of end of the meal expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.
Collected duration of the meal represented in ISO 8601 character format. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived.

Text description of time when a measurement or observation should be taken as defined in the protocol. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point. See MLTPTNUM and MLTPTREF.
Numeric version of planned time point used in sorting.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Planned Elapsed time (in ISO 8601) relative to the planned fixed reference (MLTPTREF). This variable is useful when there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date/time variable. Represented as an ISO 8601 duration.
Description of the fixed reference point referred to by MLELTM, MLTPTNUM, and MLTPT.
Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by MLTPTREF in ISO 8601 character format.

The name of a specific instance of a Disease Milestone Type (MIDSTYPE) described in the Trial Disease Milestones dataset. This should be unique within a subject. Used only in conjunction with RELMIDS and MIDSDTC.
The temporal relationship of the observation to the Disease Milestone Instance Name in MIDS. Examples: "IMMEDIATELY BEFORE", "AT TIME OF", "AFTER".
The start date/time of the Disease Milestone Instance Name in MIDS, in ISO 8601 format.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number to ensure uniqueness of records within a dataset for a subject. Should be assigned to be in a consistent chronological order.
Used to link together a block of related records within a subject in a domain.
Sponsor-defined identifier. Example: pre-printed line identifier on a CRF or record identifier defined in the sponsor's operational database.
Used to facilitate identification of relationships between records.
Used to facilitate identification of relationships between records.
Name of procedure performed, either pre-printed or collected on a CRF.

Standardized or dictionary-derived name of PRTRT. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms in the external codelist element in the Define-XML document. If an intervention term does not have a decode value in the dictionary, then PRDECOD will be null.
Used to define a category of procedure values.
Used to define a further categorization of PRCAT values.
Used when a specific procedure is pre-specified on a CRF. Values should be "Y" or null.
Used to record whether a pre-specified procedure occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific procedure is solicited.
Denotes the indication for the procedure (e.g., why the procedure was performed).
Amount of PRTRT administered. Not populated when PRDOSTXT is populated.
Dosing information collected in text form. Examples: "<1", "200-400". Not populated when PRDOSE is populated.
Units for PRDOSE, PRDOSTOT, or PRDOSTXT.
Dose form for PRTRT.
Usually expressed as the number of doses given per a specific interval.
Text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the procedure.
Route of administration for PRTRT.
Anatomical location of a procedure.
Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing laterality.
Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing directionality.
Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing the distribution, which means arrangement of, apportioning of.
Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.
Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter.
Planned study day of VISIT. Should be an integer.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the procedure.
Start date/time of the procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of the procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Procedure

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of procedure expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Procedure

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of procedure expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.
Collected duration of a procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.
Text description of time when a procedure should be performed. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See PRTPTNUM and PRTPTREF.
Numerical version of planned time point used in sorting.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Planned elapsed time in ISO 8601 format relative to a planned fixed reference (PRTPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date/time variable, but an interval, represented as ISO duration.
Description of the fixed reference point referred to by PRELTM, PRTPTNUM, and PRTPT.
Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by PRTRTREF in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the start of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable PRSTTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by PRSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable PRENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by PRENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a Tobacco & Alcohol use CRF page.
Substance name. Examples: "Cigarettes", "Coffee".
If SUTRT is modified, then the modified text is placed here.

Standardized or dictionary-derived text description of SUTRT or SUMODIFY if the sponsor chooses to code the substance use. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document.
Used to define a category of related records. Examples: "TOBACCO", "ALCOHOL", or "CAFFEINE".
A further categorization of substance use. Examples: "CIGARS", "CIGARETTES", "BEER", "WINE".
Used to indicate whether ("Y"/null) information about the use of a specific substance was solicited on the CRF.

When the use of specific substances is solicited, SUOCCUR is used to indicate whether or not ("Y"/"N") a particular pre-specified substance was used. Values are null for substances not specifically solicited.

When the use of pre-specified substances is solicited, the completion status indicates that there was no response to the question about the pre-specified substance. When there is no pre-specified list on the CRF, then the completion status indicates that substance use was not assessed for the subject.
Describes the reason substance use was not collected. Used in conjunction with SUSTAT when value of SUSTAT is "NOT DONE".

Substance use class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class value. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, then follow Section 4.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-Result Qualifier Variable, or omit SUCLAS.
Code corresponding to SUCLAS. May be obtained from coding.
Amount of SUTRT consumed. Not populated if SUDOSTXT is populated.
Substance use consumption amounts or a range of consumption information collected in text form. Not populated if SUDOSE is populated.
Units for SUDOSE, SUDOSTOT, or SUDOSTXT. Examples: "OUNCES", "CIGARETTE EQUIVALENTS", "GRAMS".
Dose form for SUTRT. Examples: "INJECTABLE", "LIQUID", or "POWDER".
Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of SUDOSE within a specific time period. Example: "Q24H" (every day).

Total daily use of SUTRT using the units in SUDOSU. Used when dosing is collected as Total Daily Dose. If sponsor needs to aggregate the data over a period other than daily, then the aggregated total could be recorded in a Supplemental Qualifier variable.
Route of administration for SUTRT. Examples: "ORAL", "INTRAVENOUS".

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm for the Element in which the substance use started. Null for substances that started before study participation.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the substance use. Null for substances that started before study participation.
Start date/time of the substance use represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of the substance use represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Substance Use

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of substance use relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Substance Use

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of substance use relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Collected duration of substance use in ISO 8601 format. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.

Describes the start of the substance use relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR" was collected, this information may be translated into SUSTRF. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Describes the end of the substance use with relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING", or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into SUENRF. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Description.TranslatedText: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the start of the substance as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable SUSTTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7 , Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by SUSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the substance as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable SUENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7 , Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by SUENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external identifier such as a serial number on an SAE reporting form.
Sponsor-defined identifier. It may be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on an Adverse Events page.

Description.TranslatedText: Reported Term for the Adverse Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Verbatim name of the event.
If AETERM is modified to facilitate coding, then AEMODIFY will contain the modified text.
Dictionary-derived text description of the Lowest Level Term.
Dictionary-derived code for the Lowest Level Term.

Dictionary-derived text description of AETERM or AEMODIFY. Equivalent to the Preferred Term (PT in MedDRA). The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document.
Dictionary-derived code for the Preferred Term.
Dictionary-derived text description of the High Level Term for the primary System Organ Class.
Dictionary-derived code for the High Level Term for the primary System Organ Class.
Dictionary-derived text description of the High Level Group Term for the primary System Organ Class.
Dictionary-derived code for the High Level Group Term for the primary System Organ Class.
Used to define a category of related records. Example: "BLEEDING", "NEUROPSYCHIATRIC".
A further categorization of adverse event. Example: "NEUROLOGIC".
A value of "Y" indicates that this adverse event was pre-specified on the CRF. Values are null for spontaneously reported events (i.e., those collected as free-text verbatim terms).

Dictionary derived. Body system or organ class used by the sponsor from the coding dictionary (e.g., MedDRA). When using a multi-axial dictionary such as MedDRA, this should contain the SOC used for the sponsor's analyses and summary tables, which may not necessarily be the primary SOC.

Description.TranslatedText: Body System or Organ Class Code

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Dictionary derived. Code for the body system or organ class used by the sponsor. When using a multi-axial dictionary such as MedDRA, this should contain the SOC used for the sponsor's analyses and summary tables, which may not necessarily be the primary SOC.
Dictionary-derived text description of the primary System Organ Class. Will be the same as AEBODSYS if the primary SOC was used for analysis.
Dictionary-derived code for the primary System Organ Class. Will be the same as AEBDSYCD if the primary SOC was used for analysis.
Describes anatomical location relevant for the event (e.g., "ARM" for skin rash).
The severity or intensity of the event. Examples: "MILD", "MODERATE", "SEVERE".
Is this a serious event? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Describes changes to the study treatment as a result of the event. AEACN is specifically for the relationship to study treatment. AEACNOTH is for actions unrelated to dose adjustments of study treatment. Examples of AEACN values include ICH E2B values: "DRUG WITHDRAWN", "DOSE REDUCED", "DOSE INCREASED", "DOSE NOT CHANGED", "UNKNOWN" or "NOT APPLICABLE".

Describes other actions taken as a result of the event that are unrelated to dose adjustments of study treatment. Usually reported as free text. Example: "TREATMENT UNBLINDED. PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN NOTIFIED".

Records the investigator's opinion as to the causality of the event to the treatment. ICH E2A and E2B examples include "NOT RELATED", "UNLIKELY RELATED", "POSSIBLY RELATED", "RELATED". Controlled Terminology may be defined in the future. Check with regulatory authority for population of this variable.
Records the investigator's opinion as to whether the event may have been due to a treatment other than study drug. May be reported as free text. Example: "MORE LIKELY RELATED TO ASPIRIN USE".
Used to indicate the pattern of the event over time. Examples: "INTERMITTENT", "CONTINUOUS", "SINGLE EVENT".
Description of the outcome of an event.
Was the serious event associated with the development of cancer? Valid values are "Y" and "N". This is a legacy seriousness criterion. It is not included in ICH E2A.
Was the serious event associated with congenital anomaly or birth defect? Valid values are "Y" and "N".
Did the serious event result in persistent or significant disability/incapacity? Valid values are "Y" and "N".
Did the serious event result in death? Valid values are "Y" and "N".
Did the serious event require or prolong hospitalization? Valid values are "Y" and "N".
Was the serious event life threatening? Valid values are "Y" and "N".
Did the serious event occur with an overdose? Valid values are "Y" and "N". This is a legacy seriousness criterion. It is not included in ICH E2A.
Do additional categories for seriousness apply? Valid values are "Y" and "N".
Was another treatment given because of the occurrence of the event? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Toxicity grade according to a standard toxicity scale such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events v3.0 (CTCAE). Sponsor should specify name of the scale and version used in the metadata (see Assumption 6d). If value is from a numeric scale, represent only the number (e.g., "2" and not "Grade 2").

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the adverse event. Examples: "SCREENING", "TREATMENT", "FOLLOW-UP".
Start date/time of the adverse event represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of the adverse event represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Adverse Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of adverse event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Adverse Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Collected duration and unit of an adverse event. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times. Example: "P1DT2H" (for 1 day, 2 hours).

Describes the end of the event relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point (RFSTDTC) and a discrete ending point (RFENDTC) of the trial. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the event as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable AEENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description of date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by AEENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within adomain. May be any valid number.
Used to link together a block of related records for a subject within a domain.
Internal or external identifier such as lab specimen ID, or UUID for an ECG waveform or a medical image.
Sponsor-defined identifier.

Description.TranslatedText: Reported Term for the Clinical Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Term for the medical condition or event. Most likely preprinted on CRF.

Controlled terminology for the name of the clinical event. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document.
Used to define a category of related records.
A further categorization of the condition or event.
Used to indicate whether the Event in CETERM was pre-specified. Value is "Y" for pre-specified events and null for spontaneously reported events.
Used when the occurrence of specific events is solicited, to indicate whether or not a clinical event occurred. Values are null for spontaneously reported events.
The status indicates that a question from a pre-specified list was not answered.
Describes the reason clinical event data was not collected. Used in conjunction with CESTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Dictionary-derived. Body system or organ class that is involved in an event or measurement from a standard hierarchy (e.g., MedDRA). When using a multiaxial dictionary such as MedDRA, this should contain the SOC used for the sponsor's analyses and summary tables which may not necessarily be the primary SOC.
The severity or intensity of the event. Examples: "MILD", "MODERATE", "SEVERE".

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm for the Element in which the clinical event started.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the clinical event.
Collection date and time for the clinical event observation represented in ISO 8601 character format.
Start date/time of the clinical event represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of the clinical event, represented in ISO 8601 character format.

1. Study day of clinical event collection, measured as integer days. 2. Algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in Demographics. This formula should be consistent across the submission.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Actual study day of start of the clinical event expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Actual study day of end of the clinical event expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Describes the start of the clinical event relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Describes the end of the event relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Description.TranslatedText: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the start of the observation as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable CESTTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by --STRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable CEENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by CEENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external identifier.
Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a Disposition page.

Description.TranslatedText: Reported Term for the Disposition Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Verbatim name of the event or protocol milestone. Some terms in DSTERM will match DSDECOD, but others, such as "Subject moved" will map to controlled terminology in DSDECOD, such as "LOST TO FOLLOW-UP".

Controlled terminology for the name of disposition event or protocol milestone. Examples of protocol milestones: "INFORMED CONSENT OBTAINED", "RANDOMIZED". There are separate codelists used for DSDECOD where the choice depends on the value of DSCAT. Codelist "NCOMPLT" is used for disposition events and codelist "PROTMLST" is used for protocol milestones. The variable may be subject to controlled terminology for other events.
Used to define a category of related records.
A further categorization of DSCAT (e.g., "STUDY PARTICIPATION", "STUDY TREATMENT" when DSCAT = "DISPOSITION EVENT").
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the event.
Collection date and time of the disposition observation represented in ISO 8601 character format.
Start date/time of the disposition event in ISO 8601 character format.
Start date/time of the disposition event in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Disposition Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Internal or external identifier.
Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a CRF page.

Verbatim name of the protocol deviation criterion. Example: "IVRS PROCESS DEVIATION - NO DOSE CALL PERFORMED". The DVTERM values will map to the controlled terminology in DVDECOD, such as "TREATMENT DEVIATION".

Controlled terminology for the name of the protocol deviation. Examples: "SUBJECT NOT WITHDRAWN AS PER PROTOCOL", "SELECTION CRITERIA NOT MET", "EXCLUDED CONCOMITANT MEDICATION", "TREATMENT DEVIATION".
Category of the protocol deviation criterion.
A further categorization of the protocol deviation.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the deviation. Examples: "TREATMENT", "SCREENING", "FOLLOW-UP".
Start date/time of deviation represented in ISO 8601 character format.
End date/time of deviation represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Deviation Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of start of event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Observation

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of end of event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external healthcare encounter identifier.
Sponsor-defined identifier. It may be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a Healthcare encounters page.
Verbatim or preprinted CRF term for the healthcare encounter.
Dictionary or sponsor-defined derived text description of HOTERM or the modified topic variable (HOMODIFY).
Used to define a category of topic-related values.
A further categorization of HOCAT values.
A value of "Y" indicates that this healthcare encounter event was pre-specified on the CRF. Values are null for spontaneously reported events (i.e., those collected as free-text verbatim terms).
Used when the occurrence of specific healthcare encounters is solicited, to indicate whether or not an encounter occurred. Values are null for spontaneously reported events.
The status indicates that the pre-specified question was not answered.
Describes the reason data for a pre-specified event was not collected. Used in conjunction with HOSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the healthcare encounter. Examples: "SCREENING", "TREATMENT", "FOLLOW-UP".
Collection date and time of the healthcare encounter.
Start date/time of the healthcare encounter (e.g., date of admission).
End date/time of the healthcare encounter (date of discharge).
Study day of event collection relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of Start of Encounter

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of the start of the healthcare encounter relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Description.TranslatedText: Study Day of End of Healthcare Encounter

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Study day of the end of the healthcare encounter relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Collected duration of the healthcare encounter. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from the start and end date/times. Example: P1DT2H (for 1 day, 2 hours).

Description.TranslatedText: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the start of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable --STTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by STRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the event as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable HOENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by HOENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external medical history identifier.
Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a Medical History page.

Description.TranslatedText: Reported Term for the Medical History

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Verbatim or preprinted CRF term for the medical condition or event.
If MHTERM is modified to facilitate coding, then MHMODIFY will contain the modified text.

Dictionary-derived text description of MHTERM or MHMODIFY. Equivalent to the Preferred Term (PT in MedDRA). The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document.
Specifies the aspect of the medical condition or event by which MHSTDTC and/or the MHENDTC is defined. Examples: "DIAGNOSIS", "SYMPTOMS", "RELAPSE", "INFECTION".
Used to define a category of related records. Examples: "CARDIAC" or "GENERAL".
A further categorization of the condition or event.
A value of "Y" indicates that this medical history event was pre-specified on the CRF. Values are null for spontaneously reported events (i.e., those collected as free-text verbatim terms).

Used when the occurrence of specific medical history conditions is solicited, to indicate whether or not ("Y"/"N") a medical condition (MHTERM) had ever occurred. Values are null for spontaneously reported events.
The status indicates that the pre-specified question was not asked/answered.
Describes the reason why data for a pre-specified condition was not collected. Used in conjunction with MHSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Dictionary-derived. Body system or organ class that is involved in an event or measurement from a standard hierarchy (e.g., MedDRA). When using a multi-axial dictionary such as MedDRA, this should contain the SOC used for the sponsor's analyses and summary tables which may not necessarily be the primary SOC.

Description.TranslatedText: Planned Order of Element within Arm

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm for the Element in which the assessment was made.
Epoch associated with the start date/time of the medical history event.
Collection date and time of the medical history observation represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: Start Date/Time of Medical History Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Start date/time of the medical history event represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Description.TranslatedText: End Date/Time of Medical History Event

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: End date/time of the medical history event.

1. Study day of medical history collection, measured as integer days. 2. Algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in Demographics. This formula should be consistent across the submission.

Describes the end of the event relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Description.TranslatedText: End Relative to Reference Time Point

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Identifies the end of the event as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable MHENTPT. Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.
Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by MHENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".
Unique identifier for a study within the submission.
Two-character abbreviation for the domain.
Unique subject identifier within the submission.
Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.
Internal or external identifier such as label number.

Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Examples: Line number on the Drug Accountability page, drug label code.

Short character value for DATEST used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical format to a horizontal format. The short value can be up to 8 characters and cannot begin with a number or contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. Example: "DISPAMT", "RETAMT".

Verbatim name, corresponding to the topic variable, of the test or examination used to obtain the drug accountability assessment. The value in DATEST cannot be longer than 40 characters. Example: "Dispensed Amount", "Returned Amount".
Used to define a category of topic-variable values. Examples: "STUDY MEDICATION", "RESCUE MEDICATION".
Used to define a further categorization level for a group of related records.

Description.TranslatedText: Result or Finding in Original Units

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Result of the Drug Accountability assessment as originally received or collected.
Unit for DAORRES.

Description.TranslatedText: Result or Finding in Standard Format

mdr:CDISCNotes.TranslatedText: Contains the result value for all Drug Accountability assessments, copied or derived from DAORRES in a standard format or in standard units. DASTRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in DASTRESN.
Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; copied in numeric format from DASTRESC. DASTRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.
Standardized units used for DASTRESC and DASTRESN.
